newsitem.title: CANADA: Golden Rule falls after brokerage report.
newsitem.headline: Golden Rule falls after brokerage report.

text.p: Golden Rule Resources Ltd lost some of its newfound glitter on Wednesday, falling in heavy trading after a brokerage recommended selling the stock.
ScotiaMcLeod, in a report to its retail sales team, said the stock had risen too high too fast, industry sources said.
Shares in Golden Rule were down C$1.65 to C$11.10 by mid-afternoon, with more than 2.2 million shares trading hands.
The stock has soared since the beginning of the year, to a high of C$13.10 on January 27, from C$5.25 on January 6, on the strength of results from its Ghana gold prospect.
Initial trenching results from the company's exploration property, the Stenpad gold prospect in Ghana, have caught the market's attention, analysts said.
Drilling is not scheduled to start until March, however, and some analysts have warned the results may be enhanced by surface enrichment, which is common in the area.

"It is likely to be at least two months before questions as to the influence (if any) of enrichment processes in the near surface grades can be answered by drilling," Yorkton Securities analyst Jim Taylor said in a recent report.
Golden Rule's partner at Stenpad, Hixon Gold, was down C$1.05 to C$11.80 in trading of more than 741,000 shares on Wednesday.
The focus on Golden Rule has put a spotlight on other Canadian companies active in the area around Stenpad, analysts said.
Shares in Nevsun Resources Ltd have risen to C$8 on Wednesday from about C$6.50 at the start of the year. Nevsun is exploring to the northeast of Stenpad.
Opawica Explorations Inc, which is exploring southwest of Stenpad, has risen to C$3.25 on Wednesday from C$2 on January 6.
